review.title: Argumentation-based Security for Social Good
review.abstract: The increase of connectivity and the impact it has in every day life is raising new and existing security problems that are becoming important for social good. We introduce two particular problems: cyber attack attribution and regulatory data sharing. For both problems, decisions about which rules to apply, should be taken under incomplete and context dependent information. The solution we propose is based on argumentation reasoning, that is a well suited technique for implementing decision making mechanisms under conflicting and incomplete information. Our proposal permits us to identify the attacker of a cyber attack and decide the regulation rule that should be used while using and sharing data. We illustrate our solution through concrete examples.

sections.heading: The Attribution Problem in Cyber Attacks
sections.text: The affection of people who stand up for people's rights has increased significantly in recent years, not only in the US, but also in other parts of the world.

sections.heading: Argumentation-based Reasoner for Attribution
sections.text: We will present our reasoning for the mapping problem in cyber attacks. We will show how to categorize the different pieces of evidence. We will present the reasoning rules that were extracted from a simple cyber attack and converted into arguments. Finally, we will show the use of arguments and priority rules to solve the mapping problem. The tactical level includes technical information obtained by verifying the system, and the attack code: IP addresses from which the attack came, domain names, the original language of the programmers who wrote the code, the target in the system. The operational level includes less technical evidence, such as entity or group claiming the attack, the context (e.g. political or geographical) of the attack, the ability / capabilities required to carry out the attack.

sections.heading: The Problem of Data Sharing
sections.text: There is a need not only to protect the data, but also to lead to a correct and effective distribution of data, respecting the requirements of the end user, while the data is shared or processed. Ability to respect the above rules and requirements is not trivial, since they are related to different laws and domains. They can create conflicts between the individual laws, for example by sharing the rules of data exchange with the doctor who distributes or processes the data.

sections.text: The resolution of conflicts takes place by the introduction of priority rules and the indication of the context in which one argument is stronger than another. sections.heading: Future Work and Conclusion
sections.text: There are several challenges that need to be taken into account in our approach, so that we have a basis for addressing security and privacy issues in the new connected world. The two specific issues we have outlined above can drag on in developing a general methodology for distributing data. We want to develop a good understanding of the general challenges we face, such as the problem of distributed firewall detection, safeguards against attacks, crisis management and data regulation.
